content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice idea

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy and fun CoC, especially shortest mode. :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash, in python (probably in more languages) you can use str.count(x), which makes it very simple (and short, I manged 76). Still its a cool idea :)

It seems to me that your goal was to have us just looping through the rows and check whether or not the substrings were a wolf or an owl, am I right?
I'm only asking because I'm afraid that most people will get a nice and short solution using "count" or an equivalent function, which might not be what you had in mind

I don't know, does it make it too easy? If that is the case, I could change the testdata and specify the interpretation to make "|\_/|\_/|" represent 2 wolves. That would cause "|\_/|\_/|".count("|\_/|") to give the wrong result, but I don't know if that is an improvement or if it is just making it more difficult for difficults sake?

I agree. My comment wasn't really a suggestion, it was just an heads up to the fact that the problem may not be as hard as you think.
I would wait on more comments though :)
